author: sky.cactus
content: PR that changes the specification to functioning Python code: https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/pull/2859  Would love to get feedback from authors on whether this is a good idea or not.  I was finding that trying to get the EIP to be correct was proving difficult without a compiler and tests to validate the spec itself, so switching to Python ended up being easier.  I would have preferred TypeScript, but I figured Python would go down smoother with others... if I was wrong let me know and I'll happily rewrite it in TypeScript (the type system is much better than Python's type system and thus able to express things better/more clearly).

author: sky.cactus
content: <@!740821105337434164> Not directly.  However, it will become *much easier* to price transactions so when congestion is on the decline, you don't end up overpaying and when congestion on the rise you don't end up with transactions stuck forever.

author: barnabemonnot
content:
does this
`assert self.account(block.author).balance >= 0`
need to be checked after each transaction or after the whole block is processed?

author: sky.cactus
content: I *feel* like after every transaction in case some implementations use a positive-number-only type.

author: sky.cactus
content: Otherwise you could have a miner that goes negative but gets paid in a transaction at the end.

author: sky.cactus
content: To rephrase, I feel like supporting going negative isn't going to give us anything useful, and it may make some implementations more challenging, so I prefer after every transaction.

author: sky.cactus
content: I suppose one might be able to argue that checking every transaction is too expensive, but I would want someone to actually argue that honestly first, rather than just speculating that a `>= 0` check is too costly.

author: barnabemonnot
content: if your post block balance is positive, there is anyways some order over the transactions that ensures you never have a negative post-tx balance

author: barnabemonnot
content: so i guess if you really wanted to go around the assert you could reorder your transactions

author: sky.cactus
content: The miner can, yes.  Assuming their payout isn't a function of transaction order.
